sections.title: Three months before release - steps to take
content: This section covers information for those three months before release.
Each section below will guide you with applications and information gathering.

sections.title: Visit the Resettlement Office
content: Visit the Resettlement Office, to help with outstanding resettlement issues. This removes a potential hurdle for your release.
A resettlement officer may should be able to assist with opening a bank account.

sections.title: Funding and Grants
content: If you haven’t already done so and you are seeking supplementary funding, now might be a good time to make applications for funding and grants. Speak to your probation officer about this.

sections.title: Contact Jobcentre Plus
content: Contact Jobcentre Plus to find out about benefits you could apply for.
A Universal Credit (UC) application must be filled in online at www.gov.uk/apply-universal-credit. If you need help with the application or have any questions, call: 0800 328 5644.
If you can apply for Jobseekers Allowance, fill in the online application at www.gov.uk/jobseekers-allowance/how-to-claim or call 0800 055 6688 Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm.

sections.title: Visit the library
content: Ask someone who works in the library to look up information for you on National Careers Service, Skills Development Scotland, Careers Wales or nidirect Careers Service. They have websites that give information and advice on getting jobs.
Also, see the getting into employment section and look at the Hardman Directory for ideas.
If you have the Virtual Campus in your prison, you can gain access to a lot of useful information on jobs pre-release. You might also have an Employment Hub in your prison.

sections.title: Housing Advice
content: Ask your personal officer about charities that give advice on housing (temporary or permanent). Your prison may have connections with different charities that provide advice and guidance on this.

sections.title: Find a Mentor
content: It can be difficult to ‘go it alone’. Prison charities or chaplaincies might be able to help you contact local organisations in the area you are going to.
